channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: A National Treasure, Tarnished: Can Britain Fix Its Health Service?
item.description: As it turns 75, the N.H.S., a proud symbol of Britain’s welfare state, is in the deepest crisis of its history.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A knee operation at the King George Hospital in Ilford, England. More than 7.4 million people in England are waiting for medical procedures.

item.title: Small, Hidden and Deadly: Mines Stymie Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
item.description: To gain ground, Ukrainian forces have to make their way through a variety and density of Russian land mines they never imagined.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antitank mines littering the ground at a former Russian position in the village of Novodarivka, which was recently recaptured by Ukraine’s 110th Territorial Defense Brigade and other forces.

item.title: After Suffering Heavy Losses, Ukrainians Paused to Rethink Strategy
item.description: Early in the counteroffensive, Ukraine lost as much as 20 percent of its weapons and armor. The rate dropped as the campaign slowed and commanders shifted tactics.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Andrew E. Kramer and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian recruits in the Azov regiment disembarking from an American tactical vehicle during training in March.

item.title: Netanyahu Says He’s ‘Very Well’ After Being Rushed to Hospital
item.description: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, said he was feeling better on Saturday after feeling dizzy and rushing to the hospital. Mr. Netanyahu, 73, is currently facing one of the most testing phases of his political career.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel this month in Jerusalem.

item.title: Floods and Landslides in South Korea After Heavy Rain
item.description: With at least 33 people dead, the current monsoon season is already proving to be a particularly dangerous one in South Korea, with rain forecast to continue.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: In Cheongju, a city in central South Korea, roads were underwater on Friday.

item.title: Appleby Horse Fair Draws Thousands of Gypsies and Travellers
item.description: The Appleby Horse Fair draws tens of thousands of Gypsies and Irish Travellers each year to a rural patch of England to celebrate their culture. Our photographer spent four days there.
item.dc:creator: Mary Turner and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A highlight of the Appleby fair.

item.title: Canadian Politicians Who Criticize China Become Its Targets
item.description: As China increases its reach in diaspora communities, Chinese Canadian politicians in Vancouver are the focus of Chinese state interference in Canadian politics.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.category: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kenny Chiu, a former member of Parliament representing a district outside Vancouver, appears to have been targeted by supporters of China because of his public criticisms of China’s human rights record.

item.title: Israeli Reservists Threaten Mass Resignations if Judicial Plan Proceeds
item.description: Military reserves are critical to Israel’s operational readiness. Reservists are again using that leverage against the government’s effort to curb judicial power.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: In March, Israeli military reservists protested plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing government to overhaul the judicial system. They are renewing those protests now.

item.title: Russia Doing ‘Everything’ to Stop Ukraine’s Counteroffensive, Zelensky Says
item.description: The Ukrainian leader has secured new weapons pledges, but it was not clear when the aid would arrive, or how consequential it would be on the battlefield.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Recruits with Ukraine’s 3rd Brigade during a training exercise in the eastern Donetsk region on Saturday.

item.title: Poland Doesn’t Want Migrants, but These Foreign Workers Are Welcome
item.description: A tiny village is taking in 6,000 laborers from Asia. They are needed by a petroleum company controlled by the right-wing government, which has vowed to keep migrants out.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A housing compound built for 6,000 foreign workers near the village of Biala, Poland, which has 200 residents. The country’s main political parties do not want to be seen as soft on immigration, but they also want the economy to keep growing.

item.title: ‘10 Seconds’: Outrage Follows Acquittal in Italy Abuse Case
item.description: A court in Rome said it had decided to acquit a janitor accused of improperly touching a student in part because the episode lasted “a handful of seconds” and took place in a public area in front of other students.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting against sexual assault as part of International Women’s Day events in Milan in March.

item.title: Europe’s Heat Wave: What to Know
item.description: More scorching weather is expected in the southern part of the continent and the Balkans in the coming days. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Francesca Volpi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant using mist to try to cool patrons on Thursday in Florence, Italy.

item.title: Ruined, Empty, Mined and Overgrown: Ukraine’s Forgotten Villages
item.description: Settlements along Ukraine’s eastern steppe were reduced to wreckage as the war passed through them. Now choked with weeds and with few residents, they are at risk of disappearing.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Mauricio Lima
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian tank in the village of Sulyhivka, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Alcohol Poisonings Rise in Iran as Bootleggers Defy Ban
item.description: Iran’s prohibition of the drinking and selling of alcohol has led to a flourishing underground market. But even officials have acknowledged a wave of hospitalizations and deaths in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: Illicit alcohol being served at a party in Tehran. Iran’s theocratic government has banned the consumption and sale of alcohol for decades, but a bootleg industry has survived.

item.title: As Iraq Tries to Chill Critics, Its Newest Target Is Social Media
item.description: New regulations on “degrading content” are part of a broader campaign to silence independent voices.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Dozens of Iraqis gathered in Tahrir Square in Baghdad in January to demand that the government release relatives who disappeared during protests in 2019.

item.title: As Climate Shocks Multiply, Designers Seek Holy Grail: Disaster-Proof Homes
item.description: The homebuilding industry has been slow to adopt changes that can better protect against extreme weather. Some architects are showing what’s possible.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Bryan Tarnowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: The home of Joel and Deborah Veazey in southwest Louisiana, a geodesic dome build to withstand hurricane-force winds.

item.title: Fossils Where They Don’t Belong? Maybe We Just Didn’t Look Hard Enough.
item.description: Researchers are fiercely debating whether claims about the origins of mammals result from a bias toward Northern Hemisphere fossil sites.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ham
item.media:description: The jawbone of Ambondro mahabo, a species that was 25 million years older than any mammal of its kind ever found.

item.title: Carlos Alberto Montaner, Prominent Critic of Castro’s Cuba, Dies at 80
item.description: After fleeing the island in 1961, he became one of the leading voices of opposition against the country’s Communist dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Carlos Alberto Montaner during an interview with Agence France-Presse in 2007. Throughout his career as a writer and political commentator, Mr. Montaner developed a reputation as a fierce critic of the Castro regime.

item.title: Reconsidering the Staycation
item.description: You don’t necessarily have to travel to experience the benefits of a summer vacation.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Frank Gehry Returns to the Streets of His Canadian Childhood
item.description: The renowned architect was back in Toronto for the start of construction on his second project in the city where he was born and raised.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Frank Gehry, the architect, at the site of his latest Toronto project last month.

item.title: Kerry Heads to China for Long-Awaited Climate Talks: What to Know
item.description: John Kerry travels to Beijing for three days of talks, as the world’s two biggest economies, and two biggest polluters, try to cooperate on climate action.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: John Kerry, the U.S. special envoy for climate change, is set to arrive in Beijing on Sunday to restart climate negotiations with the Chinese government.

item.title: Putin Says Wagner Can Keep Fighting for Russia, but Without Prigozhin
item.description: As Russia’s president reasserts control after a failed mutiny, he wants to sideline the Wagner leader while keeping its fighters — who have started training troops in Belarus — working for him.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in a photo released on Friday by Russian state media.

item.title: Visitors Briefly Trapped at Former Home of Agatha Christie
item.description: In a moment of literary irony, visitors were stranded at Greenway House, where the mystery novelist once lived, when a fallen tree blocked the road.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: English writer Agatha Christie, and her husband Max E.L. Mallowan, pose in March 1946 on the grounds of their holiday home, Greenway House.

item.title: South Africa Grapples With Putin’s Plan to Attend BRICS Summit
item.description: An arrest warrant for the Russian leader from the International Criminal Court has created a diplomatic quandary ahead of an August summit.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Naledi Pandor, left, South Africa’s foreign minister, and her Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, in Cape Town last month.

item.title: Contemporary African Royals, in Regalia and Complexity
item.description: A new photography exhibition at London’s Tate Modern includes images of monarchs from across the continent, steering away from Western imagery.
item.dc:creator: Precious Adesina

item.title: Seeing the World Like a Character From a Disney Classic
item.description: “Beauty and the Beast,” C.S. Lewis and other classics can offer useful ways of approaching world events, and summer reading.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, then president of Brazil, campaigning for re-election in 2022.

item.title: U.S. Cluster Munitions Arrive in Ukraine, but Impact on Battlefield Remains Unclear
item.description: U.S. officials and military analysts say the weapons, which are banned by many countries, will ease Ukraine’s artillery ammunition shortage but may not have an immediate impact in the war.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Artillery has been a significant part of Ukraine’s military strategy.

item.title: Wagner Fighters Are Training Forces in Belarus, Defense Ministry Says
item.description: Television news footage of a training exercise involving the Russian mercenaries offered a rare, if vague, glimpse of the group after its failed mutiny last month.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of foreign journalists was invited to join Maj. Gen. Leonid V. Kasinsky, right, and a Belarusian press secretary, Inna Gorbacheva, on a tour of a military base near Asipovichy, Belarus, on July 7.

item.title: A Victorian Dinosaur Park Finds Its Way in the 21st Century
item.description: Statues of extinct animals peek out from the trees, delighting onlookers in this London park. But don’t expect them to be scientifically accurate.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: A prehistoric model at the Crystal Palace Park in London gets a sprucing up in 1930.

item.title: New Heat Wave Descends on Europe, as It Struggles to Adapt
item.description: European governments have been slow to put in place broader mitigation strategies for extreme heat, allowing deaths to increase. This year may be no different.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Francesca Volpi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman used a fan on a Florence street. Since the scorching summer of 2003, most countries in Europe have adopted national strategies to adapt to climate change, but process has been slow.

item.title: Israel Judicial Overhaul: Unions and Reservists Renew Opposition
item.description: Labor groups helped delay earlier efforts to limit the top court’s power. As the government revives its plan, powerful social movements are again voicing their opposition and threatening strikes.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Israeli protesters near Tel Aviv on Tuesday during a demonstration against the judicial overhaul plan.

item.title: On his stops in Europe, Biden adds to talk of a new Cold War.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden and members of his administration, left, meeting with President Sauli Niinisto of Finland on Thursday in Helsinki.

item.title: In France, a Bastille Day With Fewer Fireworks
item.description: Many French cities canceled their traditional firework shows over a familiar issue in France, social unrest, and a more daunting one, climate change.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The Patrouille de France jets flying over the Champs-Élysées in Paris, in celebration of Bastille Day on Friday.

item.title: The French Music Maker Pone Tries to Reclaim His Lost Voice
item.description: The rap producer known as Pone, who has A.L.S., speaks through a computer that makes him sound robotic. He asked a comic impersonator to try to recapture his distinctive sound.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: A Commander Describes Ukraine’s Counteroffensive From the Front Lines
item.description: Troops with the 36th Marine Brigade have been the tip of the spear in Ukraine’s counteroffensive and have advanced about five miles into a bulge into Russian lines in southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova

item.title: The Semiconductor Struggle
item.description: The U.S. and China are engaged in a great-power struggle, and chips are part of the fight.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: United States and Chinese flags set up before a meeting between Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng.

item.title: Risk, Regulation and Personal Responsibility in Australia’s Last Frontier
item.description: Setting off fireworks in the Northern Territory, with a sense of time running out.
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: People lighting fireworks on July 1 in Darwin, Australia.

item.title: For Many Small-Business Owners, a Necessary Shift to Digital Payments
item.description: The pandemic accelerated a transition to cashless payments, forcing a reckoning among small-business owners. But there are benefits: An owner said one cashless system saved her $3,000 a month.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Schmidt
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Small businesses are moving to cashless payments. Juanny Romero, the chief executive of Mothership Coffee Roasters, added more digital payment options after noticing customers no longer using cash.

item.title: Worms Thriving in the Arctic
item.description: The unexpected presence of earthworms in the Far North could cause rapid changes in some of the planet’s most fragile ecosystems.
item.dc:creator: Sofia Quaglia
item.media:description: Earthworms could help to unlock potent greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, methane and nitrogen that are stored in northern soils.

item.title: Cluster munitions reach Ukraine a week after Biden’s announcement.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near Lyman in eastern Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: The expanded Hollywood actors’ and writers’ strike.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Fran Drescher, the actors’ union president, with other members.

item.title: Syria Allows U.N. to Use Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing for Aid Deliveries
item.description: Under a previous arrangement, the U.N. and other aid agencies had Security Council approval to deliver humanitarian aid to Syria’s northern areas. That agreement, in place since 2014, fell apart two days ago.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Bags of food aid at a warehouse near the Syrian Bab al-Hawa border crossing with Turkey this month.

item.title: ‘As Long as It Takes’: Biden Adds to Talk of a New Cold War
item.description: But that oversimplifies a complex global situation, others say, with a weakened Russia and with China facing serious problems of its own.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden arrives for a news conference Thursday in Helsinki where he spoke about “this critical moment in history, this inflection point, the world watching to see.”

item.title: Russian General Ivan Popov Denounces Military Leadership Amid Turmoil
item.description: The Wagner group mutiny three weeks ago has exposed dissension and fueled a shake-up in the Russian military, as it tries to fend off a Ukrainian advance.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media in September showing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, with Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu to his right, and Chief of the General Staff of Russian Armed Forces Valery Gerasimov to his left, overseeing military exercises in the far eastern Primorsky Region, Russia.

item.title: Aspartame is Possibly Linked to Cancer in Humans, the WHO Says
item.description: The F.D.A. and the powerful beverage industry protested the new findings, and a second W.H.O. group stood by its standard that the sweetener is generally safe.
item.dc:creator: Christina Jewett
item.category: International Agency for Research on Cancer
item.media:description: Aspartame, one of six sweeteners approved by U.S. regulators, is found in thousands of products, from packets of Equal to many low-sugar yogurts, sugar-free gum, diet sodas, teas and sports and energy drinks.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Thailand in Turmoil
item.description: Also, an industry-wide strike in Hollywood, floods in Delhi and Netflix’s Asia strategy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Pita Limjaroenrat, leader of the Move Forward Party and a candidate for Thailand prime minister, speaking at the Parliament on Thursday, in Bangkok.

item.title: Republicans Assail Kerry Before His Climate Talks With China
item.description: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, was criticized by Republicans as being too soft on China, the world’s biggest polluter.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: The president’s climate envoy, John Kerry, during a House subcommittee hearing on Thursday. It would be “malpractice of the highest order, diplomatic and political,” for the U.S. not to hold climate talks with China, he said.

item.title: Biden Says the U.S. Is Open to a Prisoner Swap to Free Evan Gershkovich
item.description: The president confirmed that a ‘process is underway’ during a news conference in Finland.
item.dc:creator: Gabriela Sá Pessoa
item.media:description: President Biden during a news conference at the Presidential Palace in Helsinki, Finland, on Thursday.

item.title: BBC’s Coverage of Huw Edwards’s Behavior Raises Questions of Its Own
item.description: The BBC is no ordinary media outlet and its presenter is no ordinary journalist. But the network’s wall-to-wall coverage has raised questions of its own.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Ian West/Press Association, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Huw Edwards in London in March.

item.title: Burger King Thailand’s ‘Real Cheeseburger’: All Cheese, No Meat
item.description: The latest fast-food stunt to sweep the internet is the “Real Cheeseburger” from Burger King Thailand, 20 slices of American cheese on a bun with no sauce or meat.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Surviving Extreme Heat
item.description: A dispatch from Phoenix.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mutual aid volunteer hands out ice and water in Phoenix.

item.title: ‘They’re Outsmarting Us’: Birds Build Nests from Anti-Bird Spikes
item.description: Strips of sharp metal pins are meant to keep birds away from buildings. Some birds are stealing them to build their nests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Mass Grave With Dozens of Bodies Uncovered in Sudan, U.N. Says
item.description: As war rages in Sudan, the United Nations said the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces and its allies were responsible for killing at least 87 people in the western region of Darfur.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A covered body in El Geneina, West Darfur state, Sudan, on June 16.

item.title: Blinken Meets China’s Top Diplomat in Latest Bid to Ease Tensions
item.description: In their second meeting in less than a month, the secretary of state spoke to China’s envoy, Wang Yi, about ‘managing competition’ amid reports of a potential Chinese hack.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken with China’s top envoy, Wang Yi, on Thursday.

item.title: Leaks Can Make Natural Gas as Bad as Coal for Climate, Study Says
item.description: The findings cast doubt on the idea that natural gas can serve as a transitional fuel to a future powered entirely by renewables like solar and wind.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Flaring natural gas in the Permian Basin near Stanton, Texas.

item.title: Biden Vows to Defend ‘Every Inch’ of NATO Alliance in Finland
item.description: In Finland, the president depicted the current moment as “an inflection point” in which decisions made now would “determine the course of history.”
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and James C. McKinley Jr.
item.media:description: President Biden arriving for a news conference in Helsinki on Thursday.

item.title: Zelensky Leaves NATO Summit With Mixed Results
item.description: The Ukrainian leader secured new pledges of weapons and reaffirmed security commitments from Western allies, but it was not clear how significant a boost they could provide for his country’s counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine leaving after a news conference during the NATO summit in Vilnius, Lithuania, on Wednesday.

item.title: Red Fort Floods in Delhi as Evacuations Are Ordered
item.description: The authorities warned of widespread flooding in the Indian capital after days of torrential rains claimed dozens of lives in neighboring states.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: People carrying bulls to safety through the flooded waters of Yamuna River after heavy monsoon rains in New Delhi on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Pledges Long-Term Backing for Ukraine, but a U.S. Election Looms
item.description: Citing American politics, some NATO leaders expressed concern that Washington could waver in its support if there were a shift in power.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking at the NATO summit in Vilnius, Lithuania, on Wednesday. Mr. Zelensky said the summit had given Ukraine a “significant security victory.”

item.title: Compounding Disasters
item.description: America’s compounding natural disasters show the reality of climate change.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mia Sosa, 9, takes a break from the heat in an air-conditioned community center in Phoenix, Arizona.

item.title: Bucha gets a remake, but pain lingers behind the facade.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
